name: Orange
summary: I'm wired and running on adrenaline
feelings: wired, jittery, activated, primed, charged, restless
description: When you're in the Orange zone, you're feeling wired and running on adrenaline.
science: In this zone, your brain enters high alert, flooded with stimulation and urgency. Cortisol levels rise, sharpening your senses and preparing you for action.
strategies: Start by noticing the surge – you're buzzing with potential or pressure. Then, choose one thing to channel it into before it spirals. Finally, act decisively but gently, and build in a pause to reset before moving onto the next thing.

name: Yellow
feelings: excited, enthusiastic, energetic, vibrant, joyful, playful
description: When you're in the Yellow zone, you're feeling excited and elevated inside.
science: In this zone, your brain releases a surge of dopamine, boosting your energy and brightening your mind. You're switched on, buzzing, and ready to engage.
strategies: First, ride the wave – let your energy expand and fuel what matters most. Then, focus it with intention by picking one bold action that lights you up. Finally, take a moment to reflect on how good it feels to be in your element.

name: Lime
feelings: optimistic, hopeful, uplifted, encouraged, inspired, curious
description: When you're in the Lime zone, you're feeling optimistic and looking ahead.
science: In this zone, your brain leans into possibility, guided by gentle dopamine and forward-focused thinking. Motivation builds as you imagine what's next.
strategies: Start by noticing how steady and capable you feel – this is your zone of sustainable drive. Then, use this clarity to map out what needs your attention today. Finally, lean in – you've got the presence and energy to make real progress.

name: Green
feelings: glad, proud, assured, seen, heard, understood
description: When you're in the Green zone, you're feeling glad and emotionally balanced.
science: In this zone, your brain recognises emotional safety and social connection. Oxytocin and serotonin support trust, belonging, and steady internal balance.
strategies: First, anchor yourself in the calm – this is emotional equilibrium. Then, reach out or reconnect with something meaningful: a person, a purpose, a plan. Finally, protect this balance by moving slowly and choosing what to let in.

name: Mint
summary: I'm content and at ease with life
feelings: content, satisfied, fulfilled, comfortable, settled, relieved
description: When you're in the Mint zone, you're feeling content and at ease with life.
science: In this zone, your brain registers low threat and high satisfaction. Your parasympathetic system promotes rest, digestion, and a quiet sense of ease.
strategies: Begin by taking a deep breath and noticing the space you're in – soft, open, unhurried. Then, bring gentle focus to something that requires care or detail. Finally, give yourself permission to move at your own pace – it's more than enough.

name: Cyan
summary: I'm relaxed and my body is at rest
feelings: relaxed, calm, peaceful, tranquil, serene, chilled
description: When you're in the Cyan zone, you're feeling relaxed and your body is at rest.
science: In this zone, your brain signals safety and downregulation. Muscles soften, breathing slows, and your body returns to a restful baseline.
strategies: First, drop your shoulders and let the tension go – you're safe to exhale here. Then, let your mind drift without needing to solve or perform. Finally, protect your peace by avoiding unnecessary input or urgency for a little while longer.

name: Azure
summary: I'm tired and running on empty
feelings: tired, drowsy, sleepy, weary, flat, meh
description: When you're in the Azure zone, you're feeling tired and running on empty.
science: In this zone, your brain shows signs of low alertness and reduced stimulation. Energy reserves run low, making it harder to focus, respond, or stay engaged.
strategies: Start by noticing the stillness – you don't have to force clarity. Then, lean into simple comforts or solitude without needing to push. Finally, trust that slowness is a signal, not a setback.

name: Blue
summary: I'm sad and weighed down inside
feelings: sad, gloomy, heavy, low, lonely, down
description: When you're in the Blue zone, you're feeling sad and weighed down inside.
science: In this zone, your brain is low in dopamine, which reduces motivation and slows cognitive processing. Emotions feel heavier, and it's harder to get moving or stay engaged.
strategies: First, name the flatness without judgement. Then, give yourself full permission to go gently – you're not lazy, you're low. Finally, choose the smallest act of care you can manage, and let that be enough.

name: Violet
summary: I'm discouraged and losing my way
feelings: discouraged, disappointed, defeated, hopeless, ashamed, embarrassed
description: When you're in the Violet zone, you're feeling discouraged and losing your way.
science: In this zone, your brain struggles to see a way forward, with dopamine pathways quieting. You may feel stuck, withdrawn, or unsure of your worth.
strategies: Start by saying, even quietly, “Something feels off.” Then, ask yourself if you need comfort, clarity, or just time. Finally, choose one small step that helps you feel a little more anchored — even a warm drink or a deep breath counts.

name: Plum
feelings: upset, uneasy, unsettled, vulnerable, hurt, neglected
description: When you're in the Plum zone, you're feeling upset and emotionally shaken.
science: In this zone, your brain senses emotional disconnection or threat. Stress responses activate as you scan for signs of rejection, exclusion, or pain.
strategies: First, give yourself permission to feel what hurts – pain is valid and real. Then, consider whether it helps to be alone or to be heard. Finally, take a step toward healing – through connection, compassion, or simply naming what's true for you.

name: Maroon
feelings: overwhelmed, panicked, anxious, stressed, frustrated, uncomfortable
description: When you're in the Maroon zone, you're feeling overwhelmed and at capacity.
science: In this zone, your brain responds to overload and escalating demand. Your stress system narrows focus and diverts energy to immediate survival.
strategies: Begin by recognising the friction – irritation is often a messenger. Then, pause before reacting and explore what's underneath the surface. Finally, release the heat through movement, breath, or expression – before it builds too high.

name: Red
summary: I'm mad and my body is fired up
feelings: mad, angry, irritated, annoyed, offended, tense
description: When you're in the Red zone, you're feeling mad and your body is fired up.
science: In this zone, your brain perceives threat and prepares for conflict. Muscles tighten, breathing quickens, and your body shifts into mobilisation.
strategies: First, stop and create space – emotional overwhelm needs room to breathe. Then, ground yourself with something physical: water, movement, even counting. Finally, don't rush the calm – give your body time to come back to centre.
